body:
I'm no expert; I just started using `Jade` in the past few days and discovered yesterday that it was renamed `Pug`.

However, I think that filters now need to be passed in as `filters` to options via [jstransformers](https://github.com/jstransformers).

To use the filter `:marked` for markdown, this worked for me:

```
require("pug").render(pugString, { filters: [ require('jstransformer-marked') ] })
```

If anyone has more experience with `Pug`, please chime in.

Yeah I was reading about that but I didn't know if that was locked down to just jstransformer filters. I will need to see how to make my own then.

Here is an example of how it currently works in Jade. This is used to render Lorem text locally and on export to use the CMS driven scripting language of your choose. (*.licoffee)

```
      jade.filters.content = (block) ->
        blockArray = block.split('||')
        localBlock = blockArray[0].trim()

        jade.render localBlock, { lorem: lorem }
```

Here it is in use. (*.jade)

```
        :content
          | 1(888) 555-55555 || ${contactus.prettyPhoneNumber}
```

Any thoughts on that?

I found some hidden documentation, don't know if its up to date.. lol https://github.com/pugjs/pug/blob/0610bdf6f58804a518322b7c002a4402e7bc0ce3/docs/views/reference/filters.pug
Ah perfect, so its in the render function.. I didn't see that. I kept looking in the root for `filters` which is how Jade was :) I will give this a shot, thanks!

If I am using pug in express, is there a way to set some filters for all calls to res.render?
Preferably in a way that would allow me to add more for specific calls.

issue.title: How to define/install custom filter?

repository.name: pug
repository.description: Pug â€“ robust, elegant, feature rich template engine for Node.js

body: @jceipek @ForbesLindesay In both jstransformer and inline filter declaration, what actually specifies the name of the filter?! Where is ":markdown" defined, vs ":potatoes"?
@ForbesLindesay Where would "pugString" come from? In Jade you return a block in the callback?

@qm3ster, for the most recent documentation see https://github.com/pugjs/pug/blob/master/docs/views/reference/filters.pug. That tells you pretty muh everything you need to know about filters in Pug. We haven't gotten time to convert it to HTML yet but the Pug file is the most we have right now. Hope it helps.

@zmanring, `pugString` is just a placeholder.
Thanks Tim, with some finagling I got it working as intended. Thank you for your help and understanding.
@TimothyGu Is there a way to pass in `local` data into a filter? I know you can pass in options `:filter(option1, option2)` but can I do something like `filter(options!=#{local})`?
@zmanring  no because filters are handled at compile time.  They cannot depend on runtime information.

@qm3ster, first, you most likely want to use the already-existing jstransformer-marked module. Second, the exported `render` function takes three arguments, not just two, with the last being `locals`; OTOH marked takes three arguments as well, but the last is `callback`. That's why they are not compatible.
